item.title: Sir Ben Ainslie remains sceptical over possible return of monohulls to America's Cup - The Telegraph
item.description:
Sir Ben Ainslie remains sceptical over possible return of monohulls to America's Cup  The Telegraph

Sir Ben Ainslie’s Land Rover BAR team say they have not yet received any official communication from Emirates Team New Zealand regarding the new class of boat for the 36th America’s Cup, despite a statement from the defenders yesterday suggesting that sailing’s most prestigious event would be moving to a “spectacular monohull yacht” for the next edition. As defenders, New Zealand have the right to decide on the new protocols. However, Ainslie said after the Kiwis 7-1 win over Oracle Team USA in the final of the 34th Cup in June that he felt it would be a “mistake” to go back to mono...

item.title: Former America’s Cup holders to launch new world sailing series - The Telegraph
item.description:
Former America’s Cup holders to launch new world sailing series  The Telegraph

A new world sailing series called SailGP, set up by former America’s Cup holders Larry Ellison and Sir Russell Coutts and using the foiling 50ft catamarans from the last America’s Cup in Bermuda, was launched in London on Wednesday night. The series, which will feature six teams including a British entry skippered by former Olympian Dylan Fletcher, is sure to attract comparisons with the America’s Cup, not least because of the presence of Coutts, Ellison and Tom Slings, who will skipper the Australian boat. Sir Ben Ainslie’s former backer Sir Keith Mills is also involved in organising the B...

item.title: America's Cup: Britain's richest man targets Auld Mug - CNN
item.description:
America's Cup: Britain's richest man targets Auld Mug  CNN

Britain's richest person Jim Ratcliffe (left) is pumping $141 million into Ben Ainslie's quest to win the 36th America's Cup in New Zealand in 2021. Lloyd Images/Getty Images The team is known as Ineos Team UK, named after the Ineos petrochemical company which has made Ratcliffe a $26.9 billion fortune. The outfit has launched a radical test boat based on the 75-foot foiling monohull that will be used in Auckland. Harry KH/INEOS TEAM UK That's because defender Team New Zealand scrapped the multihulls from Bermuda 2017 and opted for an unproven foiling monohull, to be known as an AC75. Ineos...

item.title: The return of the greatest team you've never heard of - CNN
item.description:
The return of the greatest team you've never heard of  CNN

It is arguably the greatest team you've never heard of. Undefeated between 1851 and 1983, it successfully defended the oldest trophy in sport no less than 24 times -- a feat often recognized as the longest winning streak in sports history. That team is the New York Yacht Club (NYYC) and this year it has returned to the America's Cup for the first time in 15 years. READ: What's it like sailing the world with a baby? READ: The one-armed woman sailing solo around the world The next edition of sailing's most coveted trophy doesn't take place until 2021 in Auckland, New Zealand, but the team has...

item.title: The NY Yacht Club returns to the America's Cup - CNN
item.description:
The NY Yacht Club returns to the America's Cup  CNN

The New York Yacht Club is the most successful team in America's Cup history, but has been out of the competition since 2003. It returns for 2021. ©2018 Cable News Network, Inc. A Time Warner Company. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: Ben Ainslie strikes $153m deal to fund second America's Cup bid - CNN
item.description:
Ben Ainslie strikes $153m deal to fund second America's Cup bid  CNN

Ben Ainslie didn't become Britain's most successful sailor by ducking tough decisions. On Thursday, the four-time Olympic sailing gold medalist announced a shock £110 million ($153m) shakeup of his former Land Rover BAR America's Cup team. The 41-year-old unveiled the record title sponsorship from INEOS, a petrochemicals company owned by Britain's second-richest man James Ratcliffe. The new look INEOS TEAM GB ends a four-year collaboration with British car brand Jaguar Land Rover, as Ainslie accelerates his second attempt to win the America's Cup for Britain. In a joint statement with INEOS...

item.title: Sir Ben Ainslie reveals radical shake-up of Britain's America's Cup team thanks to £110m INEOS backing - The Telegraph
item.description:
Sir Ben Ainslie reveals radical shake-up of Britain's America's Cup team thanks to £110m INEOS backing  The Telegraph

Sir Ben Ainslie has announced a radical shake-up of his America’s Cup team, with INEOS, one of the world’s largest manufacturing companies, ploughing £110 million into his challenge to bring sport’s oldest international trophy back to Britain. As part of its investment – the biggest ever British America’s Cup investment – INEOS will take over naming rights, with Ainslie’s name no longer forming part of the official team title. The Portsmouth-based team will henceforth be known as INEOS Team GB, as opposed to Land Rover BAR [the BAR having stood for Ben Ainslie Racing]. The deal, which was a...

item.title: Why the next America's Cup is going back to basics - CNN
item.description:
Why the next America's Cup is going back to basics  CNN

After New Zealand regained the America's Cup from Oracle Team USA last year in Bermuda, what's next for the oldest trophy in international sport? For this month's edition of Main Sail, CNN headed to New Zealand to find out. As the defenders of sailing's most prestigious prize, New Zealand won the right to host the 2021 America's Cup finals and decide what class of boat will be used. For Emirates Team New Zealand, there was really only one option. Instead of the twin-hulled foiling catamarans that competed at last year's America's Cup finals on the Great Sound of Bermuda, the 36th edition of...
